meanings.definition: To deprive of power or authority.
meanings.sent1: The king decided to disman the council's authority.
meanings.sent2: The new law would disman the old rules of the land.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous fairy used her magic to disman the mayor's power temporarily.
meanings.sent4: The storm's fury seemed to disman the once mighty castle.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's arrival would disman the villain's control over the city.

meanings.definition: To strip of equipment or furnishings.
meanings.sent1: The soldiers had to disman their heavy armor before entering the peaceful village.
meanings.sent2: The moving crew would disman the furniture carefully to avoid any damage.
meanings.sent3: The playful puppy managed to disman the neatly arranged pillows on the couch.
meanings.sent4: The wind's force seemed to disman the fragile tent in seconds.
meanings.sent5: The mechanic had to disman the engine to find the source of the problem.

meanings.sent1: The teacher had to disman the group of students who were causing a disturbance.
meanings.sent2: The organization decided to disman after facing internal conflicts.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick would disman the audience into laughter.
meanings.sent4: The morning sun's rays seemed to disman the darkness of the night.
meanings.sent5: The music festival would disman the crowd into smaller groups as they dispersed.
